repnme.cdata!: Africa - Eastern Nile Planning Model Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Eastern Nile Planning
            Model Project for Africa were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory; risk to development outcome was moderate; Bank
            performance was satisfactory and grantee performance was
            moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned includes: one
            of the key lessons that this project illustrated was the
            need to have a project design that focus on end goals and
            not be too rigid in the implementation modalities to achieve
            these. A key lesson learned has been that, in complex river
            basins with largely entrenched government positions, it is
            critical to broaden the stakeholder pool for engagement.
            Often, such projects support the development of high-quality
            multi-sectoral knowledge bases, modeling tools, and
            technical reports. However, these often remain accessible
            only by a select few, and new researchers and technical
            specialists have to often start from scratch. A key decision
            that has to be made when embarking on the analysis of a
            basin as complex as the Eastern Nile is to be decide which
            modeling framework should be utilized. For effective
            communication of complex issues in the Eastern Nile and
            change entrenched mindsets, it is critical that information
            be communicated in customized ways to target different
            stakeholders. It is often difficult to effectively engage
            potential users of knowledge and analytical systems without
            something to show initially. If early efforts are done to
            pilot the knowledge base and tools, it would be easier to
            attract a range of potential users and keep them engaged
            throughout the process.

repnme.cdata!:
Africa - Eastern Nile Planning Model :
            project paper

abstracts.cdata!:
The closing date for the Nile Basic
            Trust Fund (NBTF) Grant for the Africa, Eastern Nile
            Planning Model Project will be extended from October 30,
            2012 until December 31, 2012. The proposed extension of two
            months till December 31, 2012 is necessary to bring the
            project to an orderly closure building on its recent
            momentum. In particular, this minor extension will allow the
            project to be consistent with the Nile Basin Decision
            Support System activities (given the close
            inter-relationship of activities that is being pursued with
            ENPM) and allow for continuity into a new overall NBI
            project that is expected to start on January 1, 2013. This
            will enable the Eastern Nile Technical Regional Office
            (ENTRO) to systematically complete its internship program
            under the project and complete the training and capacity
            development activities related to spatial analysis, model
            development, knowledge products, and portal development
            under the project. ENTRO has in place an appropriate action
            plan to complete this project by the new closing date.

repnme.cdata!:
Eastern Africa - Eastern Nile Planning
            Model Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Eastern Nile
            Planning Model Project for Eastern Africa is that countries
            in the Eastern Nile adopt an improved decision support
            modeling framework to identify water-related investments and
            evaluate them in a regional context. There are three
            components to the project, the first component being
            knowledge base development. The knowledge base developed
            will provide a shared, synoptic view of the Eastern Nile
            basins, including its opportunities and risks as viewed from
            an economic, environmental and social perspective.  Baseline
            data will be organized systematically in a Geographic
            Information System (GIS) platform with an associated web
            portal. Effective use will be made of modern datasets from
            satellite remote sensing and other global or regional
            datasets. The second component is the modeling system. The
            models will build on a water systems 'spine' using
            tools developed by the Nile Basin Decision Support System
            (DSS) to help analyze the economic, environmental and social
            aspects of investments in a water resources systems
            framework and to evaluate alternative scenarios of the
            future.  The tools developed will draw upon and contribute
            to the knowledge base developed and will be flexible to
            adapt to changing needs and increasing information
            availability. Finally, the third component is the
            institutional and human capacity building.

repnme.cdata!:
Eastern Africa - Eastern Nile Planning
            Model Project : environmental assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Eastern Nile
            Planning Model Project for Eastern Africa is to strengthen
            and consolidate a harmonised institutional architecture to
            effectively coordinate and implement Nile Basin Initiative
            (NBI) programs and projects supporting the one NBI vision.
            Negative impacts include: wetlands, biodiversity, water
            quality, air quality, waste disposal, noise and congestion,
            landscape intrusion, and physical cultural heritage etc. The
            potential negative social and environmental impacts
            associated with preparation of Water Resources Development
            (WRD) investment projects will be sector specific and
            mitigated and/or minimized through the mainstreaming of
            mitigation measures in the project cycle by the beneficiary
            countries, assisted by the NBI secretariat. The effective
            environmental and social management plans (ESMPs) will be
            put into place to mitigate the adverse impacts of each
            subproject and appropriate support will be drawn, as needed,
            from national plans and institutions in relevant areas e.g.
            HIV/AIDS. No potential long-term and/or cumulative impacts
            are anticipated if the ESMPs are properly implemented.
